The job is done

The job is being done

- We use the present perfect simple with action verbs to emphasise the completion of an event in the recent past. We use the present perfect continuous to talk about ongoing events or activities which started at a time in the past and are still continuing up until now.
- The present perfect continuous (also called present perfect progressive) is a verb tense which is used to show that an action started in the past and has continued up to the present moment. The present perfect continuous usually emphasizes duration, or the amount of time that an action has been taking place.

要注意既地方
1. The present perfect continuous form is not normally used with verbs that refer to actions that are completed at a single point in time such as start, stop, finish.
2. We don’t use the continuous form with verbs of mental process (know, like, understand, believe)
